_exec_summary.SummaryText:
t to perform critical response procedures. To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, site and facility plans are promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response. Brazoria County LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program. We have implemented the use of BBP Observations and an EH&S and Me program which is designed to reduce risks.

the criteria of an RMP event require a thorough investigation to determine the causes of the incident. Within the past five years, there have been five releases of a regulated substance from a regulated process that have occurred that meet the criteria for RMP incident reporting. In February 2019, a 0.017 minute release of 0.001 pounds of chlorine gas occurred which resulted in an employee injury. In July 2019, a 0.7 minute release of 0.07 pounds of chlorine gas occurred which resulted in an employee injury. In October 2019, a 7 minute release of 13.6 pounds of chlorine gas occurred which resulted in an employee injury. In March 2021, a 5.5 minute release of 0.16 pounds of chlorine gas occurred which resulted in an employee injury. As a result of these incidents, changes were introduced to decrease the probability of the incidents reoccurring. In March 2022, a 39 minute release of 44.955 pounds of regulated chemicals occurred (5.8 pounds of hydrogen chloride (anhydrous) and 39.155 pounds of vinyl chloride) which resulted in three employee injuries.

6. Emergency Response Plan
Blue Cube Operations relies on The Dow Chemical Company for responding to large scale
emergencies. We maintain comprehensive written Site and Facility Emergency Response Plans
(FERP) to protect the safety of workers and the public, as well as, the environment. The plans
provide for 24 hour/day, 365 day/year response capabilities. The FERP includes procedures for
responding to a release of a regulated substance. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. Facility responders are trained and qualified on the proper response techniques for the chemicals associated with the facility and are equipped with the necessary equipmen

placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits
Blue Cube Operations conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

Incident Investigation
Blue Cube Operations promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.

Employee Participation
Blue Cube Operations truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning
accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have
access to all information created as part of the facilities implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

Contractors
On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out. Blue Cube Operations has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related the contractors work and the processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

5. Five-year Accident History
Olin is committed to minimizing potential risks to the public, employees and environment. A
fundamental part of this commitment is the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous
substances in and around the facility. All incidents meeting

mation is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Training
Blue Cube Operations has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these
processes. Refresher training is provided at pre-established intervals and more frequently as needed. As part of the ongoing training program for responders, routine drills are conducted. These include both tabletop planning sessions, as well as, full field responses to simulated incidents at the facility. Additionally, we conduct an annual site drill where all facilities participate.

Mechanical Integrity
Blue Cube Operations carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes but is not limited to: pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Blue Cube Operations to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modifications.

Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Blue Cube Operations. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to

Butene, 1-Chloropropylene [1-Propene, 1-chloro-], 2-Chloropropylene [1-Propene, 2-chloro-],
Chlorine, Chloroform [Methane, trichloro-], Epichlorohydrin [Oxirane,(chloromethyl)-], Hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), Isopropyl chloride [Propane, 2-chloro-], Methyl chloride [Methane, chloro-], Propylene [1-Propene], Sulfur dioxide(anhydrous)and Vinyl chloride [Ethene, chloro-].

3. The Worst-Case Release Scenario(s) and the Alternative Release Scenario(s)
We have included administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario where permitted and applicable.  To evaluate the worst-case and alternative case scenarios, we have used EPA RMP*Comp and MARPLOT.

4. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA. The following sections briefly describe the
elements of the release prevention program that are in place at our stationary source.

Process Safety Information
Blue Cube Operations maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis
Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations. The hazard analysis methodology applied is deemed appropriate for the complexity of the process. The studies are conducted and revalidated in accordance with the applicable regulations. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Blue Cube Operations maintains written operating procedures. The infor

General Executive Summary for Chemical Manufacturing
1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
We at Olin Blue Cube LLC, Texas Operations are strongly committed to employee, public and
environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.

Most facilities are equipped with process area combustible gas detectors/chlorine sentinels that are stationed at key locations and they all have associated alarms. These chlorine sentinels/process area detectors can detect chlorine and other chemicals at low concentrations. Facility personnel monitor the real-time readings and when any of these alarms are activated, they respond immediately. We have a process in place to ensure that all the proper authorities are contacted if a release occurs. The emergency phone numbers are maintained in the control rooms of each facility and are also located in the FERP.

In our industrial park setting, we have the ability to separately measure, report, and respond to chemical releases.  If a chemical release does occur, Dow Emergency Services & Security is notified and performs manual monitoring detection at the affected facility and around the site to determine potential impact to other industrial park facilities, other company sites and/or the public.  Our industrial park also utilizes a buffer zone in locations from hundreds of feet to over 10,000 ft. before potential chemical releases may reach a community. 

2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled
Our facilities primary activities encompass Basic and Specialty Chemicals Production. We have 12 regulated substances above threshold present at our facility. These substances include:
